Unlimited Flowz Everything you eat probably has been genetically modified. Most fruits and vegetables, all non wild caught meat... Even your dog is. Unless you hunt, fish, and pick wild berries, I highly doubt youâ€™ve eaten much that isnâ€™t a GMO.

Â @blindeye-phone2068Â  Genetic modification is a different thing than selective breeding or mutation breeding. Those cows are made with selective breeding just like dogs and dog breeds are.  They look sickening though, but one could say that about regural cows too. They don't resemble their ancestors much anymore and they wouldn't be able to survive on their own. They exist only to satisfy human dietary needs.

Tyynymyy Yeah, Iâ€™m not approving of it. I just donâ€™t think GMOâ€™s are bad, and most are basically the same as selective breeding. They take or add a random trait- people seem to think itâ€™s adding chemicals, which it really isnâ€™t?

Â @blindeye-phone2068Â  Â There aren't anything inherently dangerous about GMO products, that is true. In fact genetic modification is safer than widely-spread mutation breeding with radiation or chemicals which also produces unwanted genetic mutations that could, in theory, be harmful and cause for example an allergic reaction. Not to mention mutation breeding can't be applied to animals for obvious reasons. Not by decent human being.  Selective breeding on the other hand relies mostly on existing genes. Genetic mutations do occur in nature, we wouldn't be here without them, but the rate is pretty low.   Some people are just ignorant and freak out when they hear words like 'chemical' (all matter is made of chemicals) or 'radiation' (transmission of energy  through space in form of waves or particles. Includes visible light.) GMO products tend to contain less harmful chemicals, because they don't require, for example, as much pesticides because they are more resistant to fungi, insects and weeds. If we choose to make them more resistant to them that is.

+Cameron Shea How, friend, is any species supposed to live? What is the meaning of life? What is its purpose? I can tell you from a naturalistic perspective, we humans are not meant to be living the way we currently are. That includes you, using a computer. It's unnatural. The truth of the matter is, most captive animals have a more secured and potentially longer lifespan (depending on the species) than a wild animal. Most cattle in their current state cannot live in the wild even if we were to release them all, and would suffer far more inhumane deaths than the ones we can give them.   Would you be willing to condemn every one of them to that fate, including our own?

They're supposed to live in harmony with the ways of their environment, not in a factory that constricts the freedom to roam and breed and mingle without being bornÂ into a scheduled paradigm. That being said, I'd argue that human technology is natural (or at least, some of it is)Â due to our improved cognitive abilities, obviously a trait we evolved to inherit because it grants us an edge in natural selection; inherited traits and abilities are not coincidence. Would you call a beehive unnatural since the bees manipulated something to create it? I would also argue that the cows deaths would be a blessing at this point, we sexually, physically, and emotionally exploit these animals to the point where they routinely collapse and must be killed because they don't have the will to live. Also, most cow lifespans are 20-25 years, while the average in captivity is 4-5 years, but that's because that's when they're most "ripe". There's nothing humane or natural about factory farming, it's one thing when we use technology that effects only our own species; once we begin intentionally controlling and industrializing the lives of other creatures, I call that going too far.

It would take going to the National Geographic channel to find the most unbelievably idiotic people, wouldn't it? Your diet choices are your own, but please stop making eating meat or not some kind of moral position. The fact is that humans have been using animals since the birth of our existence, and to stop now would be absolutely ridiculous. Whether you like it or not, we need these animals to survive. YOU might be able to live without meat, but the vast majority of the world CAN'T. And that is a fact. This isn't some stupid moral question as to whether the animal will feel anything, or if they have 'emotional intelligence' as some in the comments have been saying. No, this actually has a definitive answer. If we banned meat globally, the world would starve. Third-world countries can't just stop killing animals to survive because you think they should eat tofu instead of chicken. It doesn't work like that in a lot of parts of the world because they SIMPLY DON'T HAVE THE OPTION.   Oh, and also? The amount of research and effort that has gone into making humane ways to process animals into meat and other essentials such as leather, etc. has clearly been pointless as some idiot will still come out and say that we shouldn't kill any living thing because there's a chance they'll feel even a millisecond of pain. Early humans hunted and killed TO SURVIVE. If they'd been those of you in the comments who call themselves 'vegan' and 'vegetarian' (when in reality they're actually making those groups infamous for being anti-meat, when it's actually a dietary choice and isn't supposed to be used as leverage for the anti-meat campaign) then I suspect we would have been wiped out long before the year 2015!

*****Â Just wanna throw my two cents in here: 1) IBS is not, nor ever can be, caused by eating a certain food. You are always born with it, but it usually shows up when you get older. IBS is when your intestines are moving food in the right direction, and then, further down, another section decides to push food back towards the stomach, because the nerves and muscles are confused. Certain foods make IBS symptoms happen because the harder the food is to digest, the easier it is to get trapped in the confusion. I have it myself. Fast foods are actually easier for me to eat because my body personally can break it down very well, while others can't eat meat at all. 2) The advantage to organic farming has NOTHING to do with health, food quality, or production. All of that is propaganda. Organic farming is to help the SOIL, so fields for crops and livestock can be used more effectively.

The lie I'm referring to is about the whole idea of veganism and how it started. Not about not eating any animal products, but not depending or impacting on the animal kingdom at all. Which is impossible. So my point is, if you were to truly follow the guidelines of the founders of veganism, anything that in any way intrudes on the animal kingdom would be off limits. And in that sense there are no true vegans in civilized society as it is today. Branches have developed within veganism I know, and there are different beliefs within the same system (like religion) but I will never see how anyone living in a modern society can be a true vegan.

One more thing, Let's say we narrow veganism down to 2 categories; practicing, and activist. Practicing ok, I can wrap my head around wanting to live like that. lolwut Q&A: My son's says vegetarian diets are healthier. Is this true? Not necessarily, says Dr. Debby Demory-Luce, a research dietitian with the USDA/ARS Children's Nutrition Research Center at Baylor College of Medicine.Â  A diet consisting of French fries and bananas is vegetarian, but few people would consider such a diet very healthy.Â  On the other hand, a diet that includes plenty of whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and a good source of calcium like low-fat dairy products is healthy whether it features moderate portions of lean meat or legumes, seeds and soy-based meat substitutes as the main protein source. It is true, however, that well-planned vegetarian diets tend to be higher in fiber and protective phytonutrients and lower in saturated fat than the typical American diet.Â  This healthier diet helps explain why vegetarians tend to have less cardiovascular disease, Type 2 diabetes, hypertension and fewer weight problems than their meat-loving counterparts.

michael chalaron ''Reluctant as a trainee may be to accept it, there is a distinct evolutionary disincentive for having too much muscleâ€”and a related need for an internal mechanism that constrains how large the muscles can become. Nature has answered that need by providing myostatin. A specific gene, named growth and differentiation factor 8 (GDF-8), produces this protein, the function of which is to stop muscle stem cells or satellite cells from becoming larger. GDF -8 in effect controls the borders on how large muscles can become. Most people have a generous expression of this GDF-8 gene and therefore have a considerable amount of myostatin circulating through their bodies, which imposes a modest limit on how much muscle mass their bodies will produce" Body By Science,pp.166-167, JohnLittle, Doug McGuff M.D., 2009

The Belgian Blue was discovered at the beginning of the 19th century, it's a natural variation which was found by farmers and was retained in the herds because these cows produce a lot of lean meat. Bad ass shit goes on in many commercial animal breeding stations . For a while also out on the everyday traditional farms. I once worked there. Natural selective breeding disappeared back in the early 80's. Sheryl B No one is arguing that plants aren't important. Of course plants are important, and we should always be thinking about environmentally sustainable agriculture, but you should also keep in mind that eating meat for energy is terribly inefficient. When an animal eats a plant, only about 10% of the energy from the plant is used by the organism to gain mass. 90% of the energy is lost due to inefficiencies. So if you want...say... 1000J of energy from meat, the animal that the meat came from had to consume 10 000J worth of energy from a plant, 90% of which is lost. Alternatively a human could just consume 1000J worth of plants to get the same amount of energy. So this might seem counter-intuitive, but if you only eat plants, less plants have to be eaten. :)

From Michael Pollan: Think what would happen if we restored a portion of the Corn Belt to the tall grass prairie it once was and grazed cattle on it. No more petrochemical fertilizer, no more herbicide, no more nitrogen runoff. Yes, beef would probably be more expensive than it is now, but would that necessarily be a bad thing? Eating beef every day might not be such a smart idea anyway -- for our health, for the environment. And how cheap, really, is cheap feedlot beef? Not cheap at all, when you add in the invisible costs: of antibiotic resistance, environmental degradation, heart disease, E. coli poisoning, corn subsidies, imported oil and so on. All these are costs that grass-fed beef does not incur.

All non-grass fed cows get injections of antibiotics because they can't digest corn without these antibiotics. As in if they just ate corn they would die of starvation. the antibiotics plus corn causes painful stomach ulcers that go untreated And the corn is grown using fertilizer made from oil Officials within the U.S. beef industry have admitted that 792,000 gallons of water are needed to raise a 1,000-pound steer, and that may be a low estimate. Researchers at Michigan State University found that 2,500 gallons are needed to grow a pound of flesh, which would mean the same steer actually necessitates 2.5 million gallons of water in its lifetime.2 Contrarily, only 25 gallons of water are required to produce one pound of wheat, 1 percent as much water as is needed for beef.  Intensive animal agriculture, a production model that is being steadily adopted throughout the world, is a vast user of fossil fuel, mainly for the production of feed.Â  In the U.S., one ton of oil (2000 pounds or 6.75 barrels) is required to produce one steer weighing 1250 pounds (Pollan, 2002). One acre of corn production in the U.S. requires approximately 140 gallons of oil (Pimentel, 2001), and if the corn goes to livestock, only about one-fifth of the protein is returned as food, and four-fifths of it is lost (McLaren et al, 1998).

*****Â It's caused by a genetic defect that keeps them from creating myostatin. The double muscling is actually a mutation which represses myostatin proteins resulting in dramatically enhanced muscle tissue growth.Â Belgian Blue, Piedmontese and Parthenais would be the most common breeds of cattle to observe this.The gene basically limits the growth of muscle. If any animal/human lacks the gene, their muscles are much larger.  A quick look on Google images for 'myostatin' shows off some other creatures with the same characteristic of the cow.  This animal has a lot of muscle but its tendons are not any stronger than those of a normal cow. If it gets excited, it can rip its muscles free from the bones. Humans with this problem appear very strong from an early age but injuries build up until they're completely disabled. So, it's not a good thing for the cow but because they produce more meat, we keep breeding them (with this defect) unfortunately. :-(Â   It is Evolution through Artificial Selection. That's how we've come to have the bananas that we know today, among other feats of artificial selection.

Wrong. Humans have fangs as all carnivores. But humans have evolved to a mixed diet, and that is shown in the relative length of animals: vegetarians have long intestines and some have several stomachs (because cellulose is difficult to digest). Carnivores have very short intestines in relation to their size because proteins are digested very fast and easily. Humans have longer intestines than carnivores but much shorter than vegetarians. A vegetarian human being is a step back in evolution.

Well, yes and no. Of course people have different habits of consumption of a variety of food. However the processes of absorption (by gross average or majority) work the same in most people. We CAN get all the nutrients we need from a plant based diet, and from what I have seen thus far in a variety of mediums, it is only when that diet is not balanced to the specific need of the person eating it that ill health befalls them; eating meat at the end of the day is eating processed plants!

Yeah, there are athletes that say they're vegan, and it is up for debate because the science just isn't there solid enough yet. I eat less meat nowadays, and don't really crave it too much, but I feel with age it's best to consume fewer meat products. I don't really hop on any bandwagon, but would rather cattle be treated with respect if we are to consume them, and limit suffering. Other than that, I just eat in response to my body -- what makes me feel like shit or not.

There are illnesses that can lead back to a certain consumption of meat. But there are too many variables to give a blanket statement like that. All meat isn't created equal, and whether it's lean or not, how often a person consumes meat, etc., etc. All meat-eaters don't eat steaks everyday. Some, such as myself, will maybe eat meat maybe 2-3 times a week, at small quantities. And people are created different hence why your anecdotes are different than mine -- there is no pure science yet.

Domestication (capturing of animals in the wild) of animals as property and as commodities became common practice.

Traditionally animals have always been mistreated. Many of the religious rituals in various cultures of the world involve slashing the throats of fully conscious animals, animals who like human animals,  feel the same level of fear and pain as we do. Naturally there's a gene (myostatin gene) that produces the protein myostatin ("myo" means muscle and "statin" means stop) which is responsible for the prevention of further growth of muscle. Once your body reaches its natural maximum capacity for muscle, it will release this protein to prevent muscle from growing any larger. Now, the type of cow that is shown, had a mutation in one of his/her ancestor's myostatin gene which hindered it useless and unable to stop muscle growth.

A possible explanation for this evolutionary bug is that while there's no denying that plants are everywhere, our human digestive systems are still way too simple for converting the most prominent plant matter, cellulose, into simpler sugars and therefore cheap energy. We don't have five elaborate stomachs, a massive caecum (which in humans is just a near-useless appendix), and enough bacteria for cellulose. That's why we evolved to eat the ruminants who do the plant resource extraction for us.

If we humans are capable of digesting plants efficiently then carnivory is unnecessary and even evolutionarily detrimental (wasteful), because of the most obvious fact that plants are everywhere. For example, cows and other herbivores don't need a supercomputer-like prefrontal cortex (e.g. tactics are only useful in nature for hunting) because they just need to eat, fuck and run to more plants.

Actually, this is not a product of selection gain in a breeding programme. It was very misleading to suggest that.  This is a genetic defect. These animals are homozygous for a non-functioning myostatin allele. In other words they have two busted copies of a gene that encodes for a hormone in the control chain for muscle growth.  What they have done is bred only cattle with this defect. Not slowly over generations breeding good performers for incremental gain.

That being said, this method follows the natural selection model a lot closer than genetic engineering in evolving animals, but in the end it comes down to some force coaxing certain genes to continue their existence in a new life. Is there a point where we stray too far from nature, where we don't know the power of own actions? Probably. But I don't think this is it. And after spending significant time working at a dairy research facility these cows/bulls looks as healthy as any I've seen.

It's not natural, but it is not genetic engineering either. This is evolution via selection, just as in nature; although contrary to Natural Selection, where nature motivates the selection, this is Artificial Selection, where man is motivating the selection. Because man is motivating the selection, and not nature, different traits are favored and plants/animals can be evolved to be much different than how they would occur in nature, and over a much smaller time period. Straightening the facts.

These animals are the result of over a century off selective breeding. They are purely natural and are great to eat. They also have other advantages: no-one here in Belgium will do bullfights (would you? :D), and Aliens stopped abducting our cows. I would actually love to see one of these in a Spanish Arena against a matador. We'll see if they are as much man as against their 800-pound-bulls. I have seen these next-door reach 2600 pounds, and trust me, they are surprisingly fast on their feet..

These bulls have a mutation in a chemical that muscle makes - myostatin. Myostatin acts to promote atrophy of muscle tissue, so losing the effect of myostatin through mutation (observed in other animals and humans) results in greatly enhanced muscle growth. You can do this experimentally, say in mice, and that results in a 400% increase in muscle mass. The leanness aspects has led pharmaceutical industry to create myostatin inhibitors for weight loss drugs.

@xXxMiyaKailanixXx Erroneous on both counts. First of all, bulls are pierced through the nose so they can be tethered to an object, and won't be inclined to break free. In addition, selective breeding is already present, through natural selection, in nature. We humans can control nature through refined selective breeding, in order to yield desired phenotypes. Anyways, the existence of the domesticated cow in itself, is a testament to human control over nature.

@thefluffyshrimp There is a marked difference between inbreeding, and selective breeding; selective breeding only targets a certain phenotype, it is not the inter breeding of a single family of animals with shared traits. Breeders make sure to maintain genetic diversity while maintaining the desired phenotype, in order to maintain population health. In addition, there is no evidence that I have heard of, that suggests genetic defects affect meat taste and quality.

@StrawKatt True. But not too long ago, selective breeding resulted in animals that, while helpful to humans, could also live comfortably. For instance, the domesticated cow was created by selective breeding, but a normal domesticated cow can still live comfortably as a cow. lol. Current extremes of selective breeding, which began largely in the latter half of the last decade, result in animals that in some cases can't live comfortably, such as chickens bred to be so fat they struggle to stand.

@JCB411abuser Speaking as an Angus breeder and beef farmer, and having actually eaten bull meat (uncastrated male bovine), I have to say it's terrible, and it's not what you find in grocery stores for consumers. It CAN be eaten, but so can any meat. Steer meat is delicious and plentiful. You castrate bulls at birth, creating steers so that the hormones aren't in the meat. You only leave the 'balls' on the ones selected for breeding - most bulls aren't for breeding. They become steers.

@cheekylibs If you consider a field full of cows 2000 years ago "Natural" then this is natural.  The selective process that made the animal appear as it does has not been a natural one -that is one free from human interference- for some time.  So unless you want to draw an aribtraty line based on the number of, say, generations that humans have been interfering in a gene pool (which you justifiably might) then these are 100% "natural" bulls.

@cjs33139 let me explain it in human terms, the reason some people are taller, Stronger, have blue eyes. etc is down to 'random' variation in genetics. What is being done here is getting rid of that 'randomness' to concentrate on the 'trait' that we want. be it Muscle or High Yielding dairy cows. If it wasn't for selective breeding all cattle would be the same animal. As a result Dairy cows are high yielding, low muscle animals. And beef cattle are High muscle, low Yielding animals.

Belgian blue muscle overgrowth is actually primarily due to a single mutation in the Myostatin (GDF*) gene.  Despite all the talk of careful breeding, this can just as easily be thought of as a natural, genetic metabolic disease in cows that happens to be useful for people. Guys this is not a genetically engineered cow. They have been selectively bred. Selective breeding generally does not raise food borne health concerns. For a more easily understood example, what most people normally think of as an 'apple' is actually abnormal! Modern day farmed apples have been selectively bred for their size and round shape. Most wild apples are small, somewhat bitter tasting and irregularly shaped. The round apple is technically 'unnatural' because it is a product of breeding.

@athiestsbane Yes and no. These scientists are isolating specific genotypes from samples of DNA that will make future generations of cows stronger, bulkier and more massive. Hitler and the scientists of his Third Reich were attempting to isolate the genotypes that caused blond and fair hair, blue iris pigmentation, and white skin, based on the idea that these traits were superior to all others. The Nazis had false ideas of genetic superiority, while these scientists have the genuine article.

Here is the scientific breakdown on these cows.During embryonic development(in stomach)muscles grow by HYPERPLASIA which is an increase in the number of muscle cells(structure of the muscle).Following birth, growth occurs by HYPERTROPHY which is an increase in the size of each muscle cell.Muscle growth is inhibited by MYOSTATIN a natural growth factor.A mutation in the Myostatin gene can produce DRASTIC HYPERTROPHY=these cows.Selective breeding isolates the gene and allow it to be passed down.

So allright, i grant you that, guilty as charged, we all have our own moral codes. So what decides who is "right" ? I guess humanity's long term survival and state of living will tell the tale. But I'm pretty sure, that abusive behaviour is counter productive.

And those beliefs include that animals have souls just like humans, but they have a different level of awareness, but again that doesn't make them inferior.  Of course all of this is basically a "point of view" thing. I don't feel comfortable killing anything, but i don't go as far as considering bacteria and mosquitoes "sacred" or something, but i think killing for enjoyment or supporting industrial level animal abuse is wrong.

Granted, nature is harsh, "inhumane" , at least it looks that way. But while nature is not a good guide for morality, it certainly is a good guide for maintaining balance. Personally i do not believe in human superiority. I grant that humans on this planet have a high level of awareness, but that does not make them superior.  Since i'm not Jewish, nor Christian, nor ...well lets just say i have my own beliefs.
I am ambiguous about eating pork. I'm Jewish, but I don't keep kosher. Considering a pig is about as smart as a dog, it probably would be a idea to have it in the off limits area of my hierarchy.

"atural processes, such as predators hunting, are perfectly okay. Predators kill as much as they need."  Nature is hardly a guide for morality. First, unless you consider our souls come from another dimension, everything we do is actually natural. Second, strictly natural processes are often very cruel. Lions, when they can't finish off the prey quickly, sometimes eat the prey alive. Hyenas eat the prey alive by default, like piranhas.   Predators kill other predators for territory, like us.

So I think it boils down to the respect with which we treat the prey. But I think there is a hierarchy of species too and it is important to consider it. Primates and cetaceans are a big no no. Then we have carnivora, elephants, psitacidieans, corvideans, falconiformes, which are pretty much off limits too. Then there is a gray area including, for instance, cows. Chicken goes to a much lighter area, and with fish it gets totally clear. No qualms about eating fish whatsoever.

@equoris ok. I think I agree with in essence. I've always hated sports hunting. One of the many contradictions of my father's is that he always stimulated me to love animals, but couldn't resist shooting the very same kind of small, defenceless rodents he'd given me as pets. I also cringe at remembering the pet rodents I let starve to death.  I love animals, but I also love meat, and I have every reason to believe it's not healthy for humans to live without it.

Consider the contrast between pasture keeping and no selective breeding / genetic manipulation, and the cows in this video.... As many have pointed out, their body is disproportional , their muscle grows due to a genetic fault which has been emphasize by selective breeding, they are deprived of social interaction, and natural pleasures, conditions.  Bottom line is, my basic problem is not with people eating meat...So be it. But at least THAT should be done with a LOT more respect to animals.

Because, in my opinion, killing and eating an animal raised in such a way, in a way that you practically respect the creature, and only sacrifice as many as you absolutely must, is far more preferable to industrial conditions.  Not to mention giving the creature the proper environment to live in. Same goes for hunting, but i am NOT referring to sports hunting...I'm referring to tribes which hunt for food for survival. They almost always respect their prey.

I think you tube might have eaten my response to your question. At the risk of posting a double, here goes again...  My answer to the first part is no, because self defence (mosquitoes bite, flies can spread diseases,etc ) , and natural processes, such as predators hunting, are perfectly okay. Predators kill as much as they need.  Even if one must eat meat (which isn't really true), there is a BIG difference between industrial meat production, and raising an animal with care and love.
So you think people should be penalized for squashing mosquitoes? Or poisoning them?  The morals have to be selective towards species. Else we'd have to start condemning all predators too.

Aren't the concepts of predatory animals having no choice in what they eat and non-sentient animals as a whole having "wants" mutually exclusive?  If you assume that animals have the capacity to want, then it follows that they also have the capacity to choose.    Animals are born, eat, procreate, and die.  That's pretty much the long and short of it.  Cattle don't think, "perhaps someday I'd like to get out of this feedlot, buy a yacht, and get some sea legs." We don't change the process.

With regard to their "cruel conditions", most cattle are raised on farms and ranches and spend most of their lives in fertile pastures.  The ones in feedlots are actually raised in better conditions than people realize.  I should know, I've grown up in the heart of beef country.

Slaughter cattle are killed with a captive-bolt pistol.  Ever seen No Country For Old Men?  If so, you know what I refer to.  It kills them instantly.  The artery cutting is merely how they're bled.  Meanwhile, prey animals are being ripped to shreds by packs of predatory animals much smaller than them.  How would you rather die?

What is selfish, is that you are only thinking of ways to benefit you. No thought to what the animal may want. No compasion about its life, relationships with like animals, offspring, or their death....only thoughts of what you want.

What is sick, IMO, is when intelligent beings like humans, choose to benefit from lesser intelligent beings.  Humans have the knowledge and know how to feed the world with healthy food and it does not have to even include meat, or at least very little of it.  However, humans chose to fill the greed with the taste of meat. Animals in the wild do not have much of a choice.

Oh ya of course they can.  It's a common procedure especially in these breeds.  They usually use a line block with lidocaine or a distal paravertebral block to provide sufficient analgesia for the animal.  So yes the animal is awake, which sounds barbaric, but they can't feel what is going on.  This is actually better as putting a cow under general anaesthesia carries significant complications (similar to equine anaesthesia).  Hence standing surgical anaesthesia is prefered.

can cows survive a caesarian or is it usually fatal?

This breed of cow is called a Belgian Blue.  They are double muscled due to a genetic defect which stops a specific enzyme from breaking down muscle.  Hence, during development they lose the balance of building muscle to losing muscle.  This is good from a production point of view since you get more meat per cow but has it's drawbacks.  These breeds are very prone to dystocia (difficulties while giving birth) and hence usually require caesarian. It's a toss up interms of production.
